elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Co(II) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, the hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated water molecules and methanol molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) Tetrahedron formed by four Co(II) atoms and six ligands. (c) The truncated-tetrahedral cage of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 1

(a) Coordination environment of Co(II) in 1 with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, the hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated water molecules and methanol molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) Tetrahedron formed by four Co(II) atoms and six ligands. (c) The truncated-tetrahedral cage of 1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">(a) The 3D <ce:bold>crs</ce:bold> single node of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (b) The 2-fold interpenetrating network of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 2

(a) The 3D crs single node of 1. (b) The 2-fold interpenetrating network of 1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0020">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Co(II) in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, the hydrogen atoms, ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and solvent water molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) View of 1D infinite chain structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (c) The ABAB packing mode of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 3

(a) Coordination environment of Co(II) in 2 with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, the hydrogen atoms, ClO4
− anions and solvent water molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) View of 1D infinite chain structure of 2. (c) The ABAB packing mode of 2.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0025">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Co(II) in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, the hydrogen atoms and Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion were omitted for clarity. (b) Left: the 3D <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> framework of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Right: a single <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> cage of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. (c) Left: the space filling mode of the single net. Right: the 4-fold interpenetrating network of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 4

(a) Coordination environment of Co(II) in 3 with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level, the hydrogen atoms and Cl− anion were omitted for clarity. (b) Left: the 3D dia framework of 3. Right: a single dia cage of 3. (c) Left: the space filling mode of the single net. Right: the 4-fold interpenetrating network of 3.

</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

N2 adsorption isotherm (77K) of 1 activated at 140°C.

<ce:section-title id="st090">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new ligand 1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene was synthesized. Three cobalt complexes were obtained using different preparation methods. Both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have 3D structures by layering diffusion method. While complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has an infinite 1D chain structure under hydrothermal method. The thermal stability property of them are investigated. The absorption property of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is studied.<ce:display>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
A new ligand 1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene was synthesized. Three cobalt complexes were obtained using different preparation methods. Both 1 and 3 have 3D structures by layering diffusion method. While complex 2 has an infinite 1D chain structure under hydrothermal method. The thermal stability property of them are investigated. The absorption property of complex 1 is studied.

<ce:section-title id="st095">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Three cobalt(II) complexes with the formulas: {H[CoL<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·4.17MeOH·13.3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), and {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), were obtained by self-assembly of the cobalt(II) salt with HL (HL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene) under different conditions. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 2-fold interpenetrated porous <ce:bold>crs</ce:bold> framework filled with water molecules and methanol molecules, in which the metal atom has distorted octahedral coordination geometry and the ligand was deprotonated. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the HL without deprotonation links two different Co(II) atoms to form an infinite 1D chain. While complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with octahedral Co(II) atom is a 4-fold interpenetrated <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> framework with chloride as counteranions and no deprotonation of the ligand occurred under room temperature condition. In addition, the stability properties of the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were studied.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Much research in coordination chemistry has been influenced by the development of supramolecular chemistry, which involves the design and assembly of porous coordination polymers with specific structures or functions in recent years, such as gas adsorption, catalysis, separation, ion exchange and so on . The recent results based on the investigation of adsorption properties of interpenetrated porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) proved that the increased adsorption capacity of such MOFs makes them as a new candidate for adsorption materials . It is known that the origin of interpenetration can be ascribed to the presence of large free voids in a single framework and it has been demonstrated that the interpenetration does not prevent the possibility for obtaining open porous frameworks . However, the factors that control the resulted degree of interpenetration remain largely unknown and/or unproven .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Much research in coordination chemistry has been influenced by the development of supramolecular chemistry, which involves the design and assembly of porous coordination polymers with specific structures or functions in recent years, such as gas adsorption, catalysis, separation, ion exchange and so on . The recent results based on the investigation of adsorption properties of interpenetrated porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) proved that the increased adsorption capacity of such MOFs makes them as a new candidate for adsorption materials . It is known that the origin of interpenetration can be ascribed to the presence of large free voids in a single framework and it has been demonstrated that the interpenetration does not prevent the possibility for obtaining open porous frameworks . However, the factors that control the resulted degree of interpenetration remain largely unknown and/or unproven .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Furthermore, it is known that self-assembly process is greatly affected by factors such as the nature of the ligand and metal center, reaction medium, template, metal-to-ligand ratio, pH value, and the counterions . Therefore, further investigation is required for understanding the assembly process. In addition, suitable guests/templates can not only transform a higher interpenetrated coordination polymer to lower interpenetrated ones but also affect the dynamic of the framework .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, it is known that self-assembly process is greatly affected by factors such as the nature of the ligand and metal center, reaction medium, template, metal-to-ligand ratio, pH value, and the counterions . Therefore, further investigation is required for understanding the assembly process. In addition, suitable guests/templates can not only transform a higher interpenetrated coordination polymer to lower interpenetrated ones but also affect the dynamic of the framework .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Compared to the well-developed coordination chemistry of transition and rare earth metal complexes with 1H-imidazol-1-yl-containing organic ligands , for example 1,4-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene (bib), 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (iimb), 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib), 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-yl)methylbenzene (timb), the ones with 1H-imidazol-4-yl substituted ligands are not well studied until now (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>) . Obviously, there will be great difference between the coordination chemistry of 1H-imidazol-1-yl- and 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligands, since the former ones can only act as neutral ligands and their metal complexes must have anionic part to balance the positive charge of the metal ions and the counteranions may have great influence on the structures as well as properties of the complexes, however, the later ones can serve not only as neutral ligands but also as anionic ones in the case of the 1H-imidazol-4-yl groups deprotonated to generate imidazolate anion. Therefore, the coordination mode of the 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand is feasible affected by the reaction pH, and as a result MOFs with varied structure and topology can be expected.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Compared to the well-developed coordination chemistry of transition and rare earth metal complexes with 1H-imidazol-1-yl-containing organic ligands , for example 1,4-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene (bib), 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (iimb), 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib), 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-yl)methylbenzene (timb), the ones with 1H-imidazol-4-yl substituted ligands are not well studied until now (
) . Obviously, there will be great difference between the coordination chemistry of 1H-imidazol-1-yl- and 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligands, since the former ones can only act as neutral ligands and their metal complexes must have anionic part to balance the positive charge of the metal ions and the counteranions may have great influence on the structures as well as properties of the complexes, however, the later ones can serve not only as neutral ligands but also as anionic ones in the case of the 1H-imidazol-4-yl groups deprotonated to generate imidazolate anion. Therefore, the coordination mode of the 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand is feasible affected by the reaction pH, and as a result MOFs with varied structure and topology can be expected.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Following this approach and also as an extension of our work, we are carrying out the research on the coordination chemistry of 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand. A compound with two different substituted imidazole groups, 1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene (HL), was designed and prepared. Herein, we report three novel Co(II) complexes with the HL ligand, namely, {H[CoL<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·4.17MeOH·13.3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) based on the different preparation methods. The stabilities properties of the complexes are also investigated.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">All commercially available solvents and starting materials were used as received without further purification. The ligand HL was synthesized by reaction of imidazole and 1-(1H-imidazol-4-yl)-4-bromobenzene following the procedures reported for preparation of tib . FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were taken on a Perkin–Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed using a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument heating from room temperature to 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with a heating rate of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and methods
All commercially available solvents and starting materials were used as received without further purification. The ligand HL was synthesized by reaction of imidazole and 1-(1H-imidazol-4-yl)-4-bromobenzene following the procedures reported for preparation of tib . FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were taken on a Perkin–Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed using a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument heating from room temperature to 700°C under N2 with a heating rate of 20°C/min.

Synthesis of complexes
{H[CoL3]·4.17MeOH·13.3H2O}
n
 (1)
Solid Co(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.018g, 0.05mmol) placed at the bottom of a glass vial was covered with CH2Cl2 (6mL), then a mixed solution of HL (0.011g, 0.05mmol) and NaOH (0.002g, 0.05mmol) in MeOH (6mL) was layered over. Over a period of approximately two weeks, the solid metal salts gradually dissolved in the solvent mixture with concomitant formation of octahedron violet crystals of the product on the wall of the vial with a yield of 49%. Anal. Calc. for C40.17H71.30N12O17.48Co (1): C, 45.71; H, 6.81; N, 15.99. Found: C, 45.80; H, 6.85; N, 15.95%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3374 (m), 3136 (s), 1619 (ms), 1562 (m), 1521 (s), 1334 (m), 1309 (s), 1251 (s), 1121 (s), 1071 (s), 965 (ms), 949 (ms), 838 (s), 736 (s), 656 (s), 623 (s).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st040">X-ray structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Crystallographic data of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71075<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were solved by direct methods with SIR92  and expanded using Fourier techniques . All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by full-matrix least-squares methods, and the hydrogen atoms except those of water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The C and N atoms of imidazole ring on 3- and 4-positions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are disordered and treated by performing half-occupancies of 50%:50%. The O atoms of solvent water molecule and methanol molecules in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are disordered. The high R-factor of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be attributed to the lower crystal stability and the disorder atoms such as C14/N13, N13/C13, and the other solvents in the accessible void spaces. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinements for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. Further details are provided in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure determination
Crystallographic data of 1–3 were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer at 200K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ
=0.71075Å). The structures of 1–3 were solved by direct methods with SIR92  and expanded using Fourier techniques . All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F
2 by full-matrix least-squares methods, and the hydrogen atoms except those of water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The C and N atoms of imidazole ring on 3- and 4-positions in 1–3 are disordered and treated by performing half-occupancies of 50%:50%. The O atoms of solvent water molecule and methanol molecules in 1 are disordered. The high R-factor of complex 1 may be attributed to the lower crystal stability and the disorder atoms such as C14/N13, N13/C13, and the other solvents in the accessible void spaces. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinements for 1–3 are summarized in 
. Selected bond lengths and angles for 1–3 are listed in 
. Further details are provided in .

<ce:section-title id="st045">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st050">Description of the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>

Every Co(II) center in the framework is octahedral coordinated. Considering the balance of the charge, the anionic charge of framework is balanced by a proton H<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, which could not be located by X-ray diffraction, but are probably bound to the nucleophilic N atoms of imidazole rings, or one of the solvent water molecules was protonated. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Co(II) atom is coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from six individual L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Co–N distance of 2.141(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and N–Co–N bond angles of 91.77(1)°, 88.23(1)° and 180° are typical for the octahedral Co–N<ce:inf loc="post">im</ce:inf> coordinations . On the other hand, each L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand acts as a linear ligand to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co–Co separation of 13.66<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. It is noteworthy that only one of the two nitrogen atoms of the deprotonated imidazol-4-yl group coordinates with the Co(II) atom.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Description of the crystal structure of 1

The result of X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in high symmetry of cubic form with space group of Pn-3 and the asymmetric unit has a one-sixth Co(II) atom sitting on a special position with a one-sixth occupancy, half of the deprotonated L− ligand, solvent water molecules and methanol molecules. Every Co(II) center in the framework is octahedral coordinated. Considering the balance of the charge, the anionic charge of framework is balanced by a proton H+, which could not be located by X-ray diffraction, but are probably bound to the nucleophilic N atoms of imidazole rings, or one of the solvent water molecules was protonated. As shown in 
a, each Co(II) atom is coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from six individual L− ligands with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Co–N distance of 2.141(4)Å and N–Co–N bond angles of 91.77(1)°, 88.23(1)° and 180° are typical for the octahedral Co–Nim coordinations . On the other hand, each L− ligand acts as a linear ligand to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co–Co separation of 13.66Å. It is noteworthy that only one of the two nitrogen atoms of the deprotonated imidazol-4-yl group coordinates with the Co(II) atom.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Observing the structure carefully, tetrahedron unit (second-unit building, SUB) is formed by four Co(II) ions and six L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands with nanometer size (b). And each tetrahedron is connected by four L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands and four other similar tetrahedrons. If removed the four SUBs in vertices, the truncated-tetrahedral cage which is composed of four hexagons and four triangles is obtained (c and ). These individual cages are connected by SUBs to form a 3D porous structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Observing the structure carefully, tetrahedron unit (second-unit building, SUB) is formed by four Co(II) ions and six L− ligands with nanometer size (b). And each tetrahedron is connected by four L− ligands and four other similar tetrahedrons. If removed the four SUBs in vertices, the truncated-tetrahedral cage which is composed of four hexagons and four triangles is obtained (c and ). These individual cages are connected by SUBs to form a 3D porous structure.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The connections of the octahedral node of the central Co(II) and linear linker of the L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand make <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to form a 3D framework with large channels as illustrated in , and the topology can be described as <ce:bold>crs</ce:bold> net (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a) with the Schläfli symbols of (3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>, 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>, 7<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) . There is large void in the single net of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as mentioned above, and according to the famous Aristotle’s observation that “nature abhors a vacuum”, interpenetration occurred inevitable. After careful inspecting the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, we found that there are two individual 3D <ce:bold>crs</ce:bold> nets interpenetrating with each other (b). It is noteworthy that there are still voids although the 2-fold interpenetration happened. The effective free volume of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> calculated by PLATON analysis is 65.4% (4711.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> per unit) filled by water molecules and methanol molecules .</ce:para>

The connections of the octahedral node of the central Co(II) and linear linker of the L− ligand make 1 to form a 3D framework with large channels as illustrated in , and the topology can be described as crs net (
a) with the Schläfli symbols of (36, 66, 73) . There is large void in the single net of 1 as mentioned above, and according to the famous Aristotle’s observation that “nature abhors a vacuum”, interpenetration occurred inevitable. After careful inspecting the structure of 1, we found that there are two individual 3D crs nets interpenetrating with each other (b). It is noteworthy that there are still voids although the 2-fold interpenetration happened. The effective free volume of 1 calculated by PLATON analysis is 65.4% (4711.9Å3 per unit) filled by water molecules and methanol molecules .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st055">Description of crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">To investigate the impact of the reaction method on the structure of self-assembly product, hydrothermal method was used. It is interesting to find that the ligand HL is not deprotonated under hydrothermal condition, which generates complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. On the contrary, ligand HL is deprotonated under room temperature condition to get complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. It proved that the structure of the complexes is unpredicted in the assembly reaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of crystal structure of 2

To investigate the impact of the reaction method on the structure of self-assembly product, hydrothermal method was used. It is interesting to find that the ligand HL is not deprotonated under hydrothermal condition, which generates complex 2. On the contrary, ligand HL is deprotonated under room temperature condition to get complex 1. It proved that the structure of the complexes is unpredicted in the assembly reaction.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The results of X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (), its symmetry is far less than complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> which crystallizes in cubic space group. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> consists of a half of Co(II) atom, two-thirds of HL ligands, one coordinated water molecule, one solvent water molecule and a ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion. As displayed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Co(II) atom is six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four different HL ligands and two oxygen atoms of water molecules. The Co–O bond length is 2.095(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Co–N bond lengths are 2.145(2) and 2.147(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The N(112)–Co–N(112A) and O(1)–Co–O(1A) bond angles are 180°, the other bond angles are in the range of 88.24(9)–91.76(9)°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The results of X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n (), its symmetry is far less than complex 1 which crystallizes in cubic space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of a half of Co(II) atom, two-thirds of HL ligands, one coordinated water molecule, one solvent water molecule and a ClO4
− ion. As displayed in 
a, each Co(II) atom is six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four different HL ligands and two oxygen atoms of water molecules. The Co–O bond length is 2.095(2)Å and the Co–N bond lengths are 2.145(2) and 2.147(2)Å. The N(112)–Co–N(112A) and O(1)–Co–O(1A) bond angles are 180°, the other bond angles are in the range of 88.24(9)–91.76(9)°.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">HL ligand has two coordinated mode in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: one is as a bidentate ligand, which has two N atoms of the imidazole ring on the both sides (imidazol-1-yl and imidazol-4-yl) coordinated with Co(II) atom; the other one is as a monodentate ligand, which has only one N atom of imidazol-1-yl coordinated with Co(II) atom. As shown in b, such connections lead to the formation of a cationic 1D infinite chain [Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. The 1D chains are arranged by ⋯ABAB⋯ mode (c) and the distance of imidazole ring between the adjacent chains is 3.71<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, it indicates that there is very weak π–π interaction. While uncoordinated ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and solvent water molecules are filled in the gap among the chains. The adjacent 1D chains are further connected into 2D network through O–H⋯N hydrogen bond with O(1)⋯N(41) distance of 2.717(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). The 2D networks are further joined together with O–H⋯O and N–H⋯O hydrogen bond to form a 3D supramolecular structure (). The results indicate that the π–π and hydrogen bonding interactions play an important role in stabilizing extended structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
HL ligand has two coordinated mode in complex 2: one is as a bidentate ligand, which has two N atoms of the imidazole ring on the both sides (imidazol-1-yl and imidazol-4-yl) coordinated with Co(II) atom; the other one is as a monodentate ligand, which has only one N atom of imidazol-1-yl coordinated with Co(II) atom. As shown in b, such connections lead to the formation of a cationic 1D infinite chain [Co(HL)3(H2O)2]2+. The 1D chains are arranged by ⋯ABAB⋯ mode (c) and the distance of imidazole ring between the adjacent chains is 3.71Å, it indicates that there is very weak π–π interaction. While uncoordinated ClO4
− and solvent water molecules are filled in the gap among the chains. The adjacent 1D chains are further connected into 2D network through O–H⋯N hydrogen bond with O(1)⋯N(41) distance of 2.717(4)Å (). The 2D networks are further joined together with O–H⋯O and N–H⋯O hydrogen bond to form a 3D supramolecular structure (). The results indicate that the π–π and hydrogen bonding interactions play an important role in stabilizing extended structure.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st060">Description of crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The HL can act as a natural ligand without deprotonation, and then we get complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in orthorhombic with space group of <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ban and the asymmetric unit also has a quarter molecule of [Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and there are coordinated water molecules and chloride counteranions in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. As depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a, the Co(II) center is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four different HL ligands with the Co–N distance of 2.143(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and two oxygen atoms of water molecules with Co–O distance of 2.112(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Therefore, the coordination geometry of the Co(II) center can be regarded as a lengthened octahedral with N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> binding set in which the equatorial plane is composed of four imidazole nitrogen atoms and two apical positions are occupied by two water molecules. The HL ligand also acts as a linear building block to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co–Co distance of 13.91<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The connections of the central square-planar Co(II) (omitting two terminal water molecules) and linear linker of the HL ligand also make complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> to form a 3D framework with large channels (22.70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>20.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (b). The topology can be described as <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> net with the short and long Schläfli symbols of 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> and (6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), respectively . The whole structure of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 4-fold interpenetrated framework (c) due to a large void in the single net. It is noticeable that there is uncoordinated chloride counteranions filled in the void of the interpenetrated framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of crystal structure of 3

The HL can act as a natural ligand without deprotonation, and then we get complex 3. The complex 3 crystallizes in orthorhombic with space group of Pban and the asymmetric unit also has a quarter molecule of [Co(HL)2(H2O)2]Cl2, and there are coordinated water molecules and chloride counteranions in 3. As depicted in 
a, the Co(II) center is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four different HL ligands with the Co–N distance of 2.143(4)Å and two oxygen atoms of water molecules with Co–O distance of 2.112(6)Å. Therefore, the coordination geometry of the Co(II) center can be regarded as a lengthened octahedral with N4O2 binding set in which the equatorial plane is composed of four imidazole nitrogen atoms and two apical positions are occupied by two water molecules. The HL ligand also acts as a linear building block to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co–Co distance of 13.91Å. The connections of the central square-planar Co(II) (omitting two terminal water molecules) and linear linker of the HL ligand also make complex 3 to form a 3D framework with large channels (22.70Å×20.90Å) (b). The topology can be described as dia net with the short and long Schläfli symbols of 66 and (62.62.62.62.62.62), respectively . The whole structure of complex 3 is a 4-fold interpenetrated framework (c) due to a large void in the single net. It is noticeable that there is uncoordinated chloride counteranions filled in the void of the interpenetrated framework.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, each metal atom is coordinated by four ligands in square-planar arrangements. On the other hand, each ligand (HL) connects two metals in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The deprotonation of the HL ligand did not occur and the Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> acts as counteranion filled in the vacancy of the frameworks in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In complexes 3, each metal atom is coordinated by four ligands in square-planar arrangements. On the other hand, each ligand (HL) connects two metals in 3. The deprotonation of the HL ligand did not occur and the Cl− acts as counteranion filled in the vacancy of the frameworks in complex 3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st065">Stability studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In order to make a nitrogen adsorption measurement, the stability information about the porous structure is required and the results of TGA analysis not only show the thermal stability of MOFs but also turn out to be decisive data to ensure an optimized temperature of activation to remove the guest molecules. For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, it is unstable when exposed to air due to lose the solvent molecules before 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Then it lost rest solvent molecules in the temperature range of 120–195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Finally, no weight loss occurred until approximately 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, where the whole structure starts to decompose (). The XRD patterns of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> simulated from crystal, as-synthesized sample and the sample heated at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in vacuum were shown in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Stability studies
In order to make a nitrogen adsorption measurement, the stability information about the porous structure is required and the results of TGA analysis not only show the thermal stability of MOFs but also turn out to be decisive data to ensure an optimized temperature of activation to remove the guest molecules. For complex 1, it is unstable when exposed to air due to lose the solvent molecules before 120°C. Then it lost rest solvent molecules in the temperature range of 120–195°C. Finally, no weight loss occurred until approximately 290°C, where the whole structure starts to decompose (). The XRD patterns of 1 simulated from crystal, as-synthesized sample and the sample heated at 140°C for 24h in vacuum were shown in .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> lost two free water molecules in the temperature range of 25–80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a weight loss of 3.80% (calcd. 3.75%), The second weight loss of 3.82% in the temperature range 130–175<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds to the loss of two coordinated water molecules (3.75% calculated). The third stage, it begins at ca. 275<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and weight loss occurs in a consecutive step and does not stop until heating to 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). The XRD patterns of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as-synthesized samples were consistent with simulated from crystal as shown in .</ce:para>

The third stage, it begins at ca. 275°C, and weight loss occurs in a consecutive step and does not stop until heating to 700°C (). The XRD patterns of 2 as-synthesized samples were consistent with simulated from crystal as shown in .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is stable up to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, weight loss of 6.45% (calcd 6.09%) from 130 to 225<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is attributed to the dehydration of the coordinated water molecules, then the weight loss occurs in a consecutive step and does not stop until heating to 750<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). The XRD patterns of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as-synthesized samples were consistent with simulated from crystal as shown in .</ce:para>

The XRD patterns of 3 as-synthesized samples were consistent with simulated from crystal as shown in .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st070">Gas sorption property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">As we discussed above, the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable even up to 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Before gas adsorption tests, the activation for removing the guest molecules from the pores by heating in vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, approximately 22.0317<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (1.30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> per gram of solvent-free sample was adsorbed at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm with a pore volume of 0.09<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g (median pore width is 6.61<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), the sorption behavior is characteristic for the microporous structure .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Gas sorption property
As we discussed above, the framework of 1 is stable even up to 290°C. Before gas adsorption tests, the activation for removing the guest molecules from the pores by heating in vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature at 140°C for 20h. The N2 adsorption isotherm for 1 is shown in 
, approximately 22.0317cm3 (1.30mmol) of N2 per gram of solvent-free sample was adsorbed at 1atm with a pore volume of 0.09cm3/g (median pore width is 6.61Å), the sorption behavior is characteristic for the microporous structure .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">On the basis of a rational designed rigid imidazol-1-yl- and imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand HL, three novel cobalt complexes have been synthesized from different synthesized conditions. Both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have 3D structure by layering diffusion method, but complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with octahedral metal center was obtained as 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>crs</ce:italic> coordination framework with water molecules and methanol molecules filled in the vacancy, while complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with octahedral metal center displays 4-fold interpenetration with Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions as counteranions and filled in the vacancy. Meanwhile, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has an infinite 1D chain structure under hydrothermal method using the same materials as complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The results indicate the reaction conditions have remarkable impact on the structure of the complex. TGA data showed that complexes have thermal stability.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
On the basis of a rational designed rigid imidazol-1-yl- and imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand HL, three novel cobalt complexes have been synthesized from different synthesized conditions. Both 1 and 3 have 3D structure by layering diffusion method, but complex 1 with octahedral metal center was obtained as 2-fold interpenetrated crs coordination framework with water molecules and methanol molecules filled in the vacancy, while complex 3 with octahedral metal center displays 4-fold interpenetration with Cl− anions as counteranions and filled in the vacancy. Meanwhile, complex 2 has an infinite 1D chain structure under hydrothermal method using the same materials as complex 1. The results indicate the reaction conditions have remarkable impact on the structure of the complex. TGA data showed that complexes have thermal stability.

metadata.title: Three Co complexes based on 1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene: Syntheses, structures and stability property
